detailed_metrics_by_round.actual_question: We're going to begin this hour discussing how President Trump is handling a whistleblower complaint from within his administration. It involves allegations - allegations that he tried to encourage or even pressure a foreign government to investigate a political rival in his family. Yesterday, the president dismissed the complaint as a political hack job. But House Intelligence Committee Chair Adam Schiff has reacted strongly, demanding that the acting director of National Intelligence, Joseph McGuire, release the contents of the complaint to Congress. Mr. Schiff has issued a subpoena to obtain the complaint, and Mr. McGuire has not complied. We wanted to understand more about this, why all this matters, so we've called someone who has served in all of these relevant areas. Leon Panetta is a former director of the CIA and a former secretary of defense - that was in the Obama administration - as well as a former chief of staff in the Clinton administration, as well as a former member of Congress and, before that, an Army intelligence officer. Mr. Secretary, Mr. Panetta, thank you so much for coming on once again.
detailed_metrics_by_round.previous_answer: Good to be with you, Michel.

detailed_metrics_by_round.actual_question: So let me just walk through it briefly. This is what we understand - that there was a whistleblower complaint. It went to the intelligence community's inspector general, who took it to the director of National Intelligence, who then took it to the Justice Department but not to Congress. Can I just get your top-line reaction to all of this?
detailed_metrics_by_round.previous_answer: Well, it - this behavior is all unheard of, frankly. The whistleblower law was intended to obviously protect those inside the government who saw some kind of abuse or fraud or crime and brought it to the attention of officials in government and the Congress and the public. In the intelligence arena, this law is there to allow the individual to forward that complaint through the IG. And if the IG finds it credible and urgent, which this IG found it to be, he then forwards it to the DNI, who shall then forward the complaint to the House and Senate intelligence committees. That did not happen. And that is totally unprecedented.

detailed_metrics_by_round.actual_question: As you said, the inspector general, Michael Atkinson, determined that the complaint was of, quote-unquote, "urgent concern." The Democrats are saying, as you just said, that the whistleblower law requires that it go to Congress. But the Justice Department - I don't know - seems to be interpreting the law differently. I'm not sure what the legal basis is for their deciding not to turn it over. Perhaps they felt knowing the contents of it that they say it doesn't rise to that level. So what should happen now? Who mediates this?
detailed_metrics_by_round.previous_answer: Well, you know, you've raised some very good questions that raise the whole issue of whether or not presidents of the United States can truly be held accountable. I mean, in addition to the whistleblower issue is whether or not there's evidence of a crime here by the president. Did he extort the head of the Ukraine by holding back foreign assistance unless that individual helped him do a political investigation into a possible opponent, Joe Biden? And in addition to that, there are obviously violations of election laws that involve foreign help in the course of an election. The defense to all of this is executive privilege. But even under U.S. v. Nixon, where the president, Nixon, exerted executive privilege to try to prevent access to the tapes, the court said that executive privilege cannot be used to shield the evidence of a crime. The problem here is that the Justice Department also has a memo that says you cannot indict sitting presidents. So the issue then becomes impeachment. Does this create an issue where the president abused the power of the presidency by, instead of serving the interests of the nation, used a national security approach to trying to push for something that was in his political interest, which I think is a violation of his duties as president? But then you have the problem of a Senate that is controlled by the Republicans that doesn't seem inclined to impeach the president. So the biggest issue I think we're all dealing with is if presidents are not above the law, then how do we hold presidents accountable if you can indict a president and you're in a situation where you can't impeach the president?

detailed_metrics_by_round.actual_question: This points to the question I wanted to speak about next, which is this seems to be being received in the moment, in the current moment, as another, you know, partisan conflict - as a partisan conflict as opposed to a conflict around, you know, substance or of national security. I mean, Republicans to this point haven't really been heard from - except for, say, George Conway, who's the husband of a Trump adviser, Kellyanne Conway. And along with the former acting solicitor general, Neal Katyal, who - they've written an op-ed saying - the headline of which is, Trump has done plenty to warrant impeachment, but the Ukraine allegations are over-the-top. Ukraine is, according to sources, believed to have been the foreign government implicated here. So how do you think we should be thinking about this? I mean, are you personally prepared to say this warrants an impeachment inquiry at this point? And we only have - I beg your pardon - about 30 seconds left.
detailed_metrics_by_round.previous_answer: Well, I don't think there's any question that this whole issue needs to be investigated. And frankly, the Republicans ought to be working with the Democrats on this issue. This is a question of checks and balances. Are we going to prevent a president and limit a president from abusing his powers as president? That's something that's not just in the Democrats' interest. It's in the Republicans' interests because one of these days, there'll be a Democratic president, and they will be very concerned if that president behaves as this president is and is not held accountable.

How can bipartisan collaboration be fostered in investigations of presidential misconduct, considering the often polarized political environment?
Given your extensive experience, how did you personally feel when you first became aware of the whistleblower complaint and the challenges around presidential accountability it exposed?
Can you describe the emotional and moral weight you believe public servants carry when upholding checks and balances, especially in politically charged investigations?
How do you think the political polarization affects the emotional resilience of those seeking bipartisan cooperation and accountability in government?
Given the political landscape's response, how do you see bipartisan cooperation playing a role in addressing the whistleblower allegations effectively?
Can you discuss the potential challenges and benefits of using impeachment as a tool to hold the president accountable in this scenario?
Given your experience, how do you believe bipartisan cooperation can be fostered in highly polarized investigations like the one involving the whistleblower complaint?
Could you elaborate on the potential long-term impacts on democratic institutions if presidents are not held accountable through established mechanisms like impeachment?
What are your views on the balance between protecting whistleblowers and respecting executive privilege, especially considering national security concerns?
If you were to personify the whistleblower complaint as a character in a drama, how would you describe its role and impact on the narrative of American democracy?

Imagine a future scenario where bipartisan cooperation on presidential accountability becomes the norm rather than the exception. What transformative changes might emerge in the political and legal landscapes?
Considering your experience, how do you think the concept of accountability in presidential power would evolve if it were taught as a foundational principle in early education?

selected_suggestion_metrics.question: Can you detail the specific allegations made in the whistleblower complaint and why they are significant for presidential conduct?

all_suggestion_metrics.question: Can you detail the specific allegations made in the whistleblower complaint and why they are significant for presidential conduct?
What procedural failures or deviations from whistleblower laws are evident in how this complaint was handled?
In your view, what does the whistleblower complaint imply about the broader issues of checks and balances within the government?
How have Republican and Democratic leaders differed in their responses to the whistleblower complaint, and what impact has this had on congressional unity?
What challenges have bipartisan efforts faced when trying to address presidential accountability in light of the whistleblower complaint?
In what ways could the partisan reactions to the whistleblower complaint affect the precedent for holding future presidents accountable?
How do existing laws balance the need for executive confidentiality with the public's right to transparency in cases involving presidential misconduct?
In what ways does the precedent established by U.S. v. Nixon guide current interpretations of executive privilege and the limits of presidential power?
What are the main constitutional and political obstacles to holding a sitting president legally accountable for alleged abuses of power, and how might these be addressed?

selected_suggestion_metrics.question: Given your experience in intelligence and defense, how do you assess the potential national security risks involved in the whistleblower complaint?

all_suggestion_metrics.question: Given your experience in intelligence and defense, how do you assess the potential national security risks involved in the whistleblower complaint?
What mechanisms or reforms do you believe are necessary to strengthen congressional oversight and prevent the abuse of presidential power in the future?
How do you see the role of bipartisan cooperation evolving in addressing such constitutional crises, especially considering the current political polarization?
From your perspective, what lessons from past administrations can inform how we handle allegations of presidential misconduct today?

selected_suggestion_metrics.question: Given your experience leading the CIA and the Department of Defense, how do you assess the role of the intelligence community in protecting whistleblowers and maintaining integrity in situations like this?

all_suggestion_metrics.question: Given your experience leading the CIA and the Department of Defense, how do you assess the role of the intelligence community in protecting whistleblowers and maintaining integrity in situations like this?
What are the potential long-term effects on American democratic institutions if the current challenges to presidential accountability are not adequately addressed?
How important is bipartisan cooperation in restoring trust in government oversight, and what practical steps can leaders on both sides of the aisle take to achieve this?
In your view, are there any legislative or structural reforms that should be considered to strengthen the mechanisms for holding presidents accountable in the future?

selected_suggestion_metrics.question: Given the deep partisan divisions in Congress, what practical steps can be taken to foster bipartisan cooperation in investigating these allegations?

all_suggestion_metrics.question: Given the deep partisan divisions in Congress, what practical steps can be taken to foster bipartisan cooperation in investigating these allegations?
From your experience in intelligence and defense, how effective do you believe current whistleblower protection laws are in safeguarding those who come forward with urgent concerns?
How do you view the tension between executive privilege and the need for transparency in cases involving potential presidential misconduct?
Youve spoken about the importance of holding presidents accountable to uphold democratic institutions. How concerned are you about the long-term implications if this accountability fails?

selected_suggestion_metrics.question: Given your experience with national security and intelligence, how do you assess the potential risks to U.S. interests if a president uses foreign aid as leverage for personal political gain?

all_suggestion_metrics.question: Given your experience with national security and intelligence, how do you assess the potential risks to U.S. interests if a president uses foreign aid as leverage for personal political gain?
What lessons from your time as CIA Director and Secretary of Defense can inform how Congress and the Justice Department should handle this situation?
In your view, how important is bipartisan cooperation in upholding democratic institutions during politically charged investigations like this one?
How do you think this controversy might affect public trust in government and the principle that no one is above the law?
